**Ingredients**
Milk 400 ml
Condensed Milk 300ml
Corn Flour 3 tablespoons
Mango 1
Almonds 5-6
ParleG biscuits 5-6
Cardamom 2
**Steps**
Dice the mangos into small pieces.
Mix cold milk and corn flour till no lumps remain.
Boil this with the condensed milk on medium flame stirring continuously. Add the mango and the seeds from the cardamom.
Stir continuously on medium flame till it thickens. Put Parle-G in a Zip lock cover.
Close it and use a rolling pin over it to crumble the biscuit.
Line the bottoms of 5 dessert bowls with the Parle-G crumbs.
Pour the thickened pudding over this. Grate almond on top of the pudding.
Refrigerate for 1-2 hours. Serve cold.
**Note**: I used Parle G biscuits because they are the most common in India. You can use any plain biscuit or cookie like graham crackers.

OOH let m kno how it goes. Little tip, kneading with hot water really helps. And mix the water slowly into the dough. If it's too sticky, rolling it out will be a nightmare. And make sure the girdle is hot enough. :)

**Ingredients**
Whole wheat flour 3 cups
Oil 1 tablespoon
Sugar 1 teaspoon
Salt as required
Hot water as required
***For stuffing***
Boiled and peeled Potato 1/2 cup
Cooked Green peas 1/2 cup
Garlic paste 1/4 teaspoon
Finely chopped onion 2 tablespoons
Chopped green chilies 1/2 teaspoon
Turmeric powder 1/4 teaspoon
Aamchur(dried Mango Powder) 1/4 teaspoon
Salt as required
**Steps**
Take the whole wheat flour in a wide bowl. Add the oil, sugar and salt. Pour hot water into this mix and knead till a smooth dough is formed. Be careful while pouring the water.
Pour small quantities so you know you won't end up adding too much, making the dough sticky.
Mash together, cooked green peas and boiled potatoes. Add the garlic paste, finely chopped onions, turmeric powder, aamchur and salt. Mix well.
Take the dough and divide it into 12 equal sized balls. Roll out one of them, but make sure to not make this too thin. Keep aside.
Roll out a second one in the same fashion. Take one roti. Place the aloo mattar mix and flatten on it .
Place the second roti on top. press and seal the edges.
Roll it out again fully.
Heat a tawa/girdle.
Place the rolled paratha on it and flip till both sides are cooked. Add some butter if you want and serve hot with some yoghurt and pickle.
Repeat with the remaining dough.
**Note:** You can pick up all the spices in asian supermarkets. If you don't find Aamchur, that's fine. What it does it give a nice tangy flavour. Instead you can add some lemon juice to the mashed mixture.

WRITING.TITLE: Aloo Mattar Parathas (Flatbread stuffed with spiced potatoes and peas) Recipe
Indian Chicken Curry Simmered In a Tea Sauce
WRITING.TEXT:
**Ingredients**
Curry Cut Chicken(Skinless pieces of whole chicken) 1 kg
Onions (medium sized) 3
Tomatoes (medium sized) 2
Ginger paste 2 teaspoons
Garlic paste 2 teaspoons
Black tea 1/2 cup
Oil 2 teaspoons
Cloves 2-3
Cinnamon 1 inch
Fenugreek seeds 3-4
Coriander powder 3 teaspoons
Red chili powder 2 teaspoons
Kasuri methi(Dried fenugreek leaves) 2 teaspoons
Salt as required
***For Marinade***
Whey 3 cups
Red chili powder 2 teaspoons
Turmeric powder 1 teaspoon
Lemon juice 2 tablespoons
Salt as required
***For garnish***
Oil 2 teaspoons
Onion 1
Sugar 1 teaspoon
Salt as required
**Steps**
1. Clean the chicken pieces thoroughly. Take all the ingredients of the marinade, mix it together and pour over the chicken. Rub it into the chicken pieces and refrigerate for 4 hours. For the people who are wondering what whey is, it's the water that collects on top of curd/yogurt. If you don't have whey, simply drain the youghurt into a mislin cloth and use the water that collects.
2. Chop the onions and the tomatoes.
3. Heat 2 teaspoons of oil in a wok/kadhai.
4. Fry the cloves, cinnamon and fenugreek till the aromas are released. Add the onions into this. Saute till they become transparent.
5. Add the tomatoes. When the tomatoes are half cooked, add the ginger and garlic paste. allow to cook till the raw smell leaves.
6. Add the dry spices and cook till the oil is released from them.
7. Now add the chicken pieces along with the marinade, add the tea and kasuri methi, cook on low till the chicken pieces are done.
8. The sauce will be a little thin at this point, but that's okay because it will thicken as the curry sits.
9. Take a pan, heat oil. Add thinly sliced onions and saute on low flame. Then add the sugar and allow the onions to caramelise.
10. Season with a little salt and top over the chicken curry. Serve hot with rice or flatbreads like rotis, phulkas or kerala porottas.
**Note:**
All the spiced mentioned are available in most asian stores. I used a normal Indian tea. You can get excellent results with chai tea or masala tea also.
Full blog post [here.](http://www.warandcheese.com/tea-spiced-indian-chicken-curry-and-how-to-tenderize-chicken-for-curries)

Ingredients
Spaghetti 1/2 pack
Salt as required
Water as required
**For the sauce**
Chopped Onion 3 tablespoons
Garlic (finely chopped) 1 tablespoons
Tomato puree 1 pack
Capsicum 2 tablespoons
Crumbled paneer 3 tablespoons
Olive oil 1 tablespoon
Salt as required
Chilli flakes 1 teaspoon
Italian seasoning as required
**Topping**
Mozzarella cheese 1 cup
Crumbled paneer 3 tablespoons
Italian seasoning as required
**Steps**
Heat olive oil in a skillet.
Once hot, add the chopped onions and sautee. When the onions become transparent add the garlic and saute.
Then add the tomato puree and cook till the raw smell is gone. Season with salt, chilli flakes and Italian seasoning.
Then add the chopped capsicum and crumbled paneer and cook till everything is well combined.
In a pot, boil some salted water and cook the spaghetti as per instructions until al dente. Drain, but keep 5 tablespoons of the water aside. Take a baking dish and spray with some olive oil.
Make a first layer of spaghetti,pour the drained water on top. Add the sauce as the next layer. Top with mozzarella cheese, crumbled paneer and Italian seasoning. Bake at 180C for 30 minutes.
Serve hot!

It's a sort of firmer cottage cheese. You can get it in pretty much every asian store. If you don't you can simply drain the cottage cheese using a muslin cloth and use that . And capsicum is green pepper here. You can use red too. It just gives hit of extra flavour :)

WRITING.TEXT: Before I answer this, I just want to say upfront that I work with Cucumbertown, which is a food blogging platform. So this is what happens usually. People blog for some time, get a loyal following over that time with a combination of good content and promotion on social media and then they get out an ebook. this way they already have an engaged user base that hey can talk about the ebook. You should check out [this interview](https://magazine.cucumbertown.com/not-yet-3-months-in-and-already-3000-up-the-first-steps-of-monetising-your-food-blog-by-samantha-ebf02209a295) we had done sometime back, where the blogger talks about what she did with ebooks mainly as a way of passive income. In my opinion, it's best to do both. Blog and get an ebook out, because with ebooks, the competition is extremely high, and conversion could be low.

500 gms Lamb meat/Mutton
1 Kiwi slice
2 Chopped onion
18-20 Dried Red chillies
2 teaspoons Coriander seeds
1 teaspoon Cumin seeds
2 teaspoons Garlic paste
1/2 tablespoon Ginger chopped to taste
Salt 3-4 Green cardamoms
1/2 teaspoon Black pepper
1 " Cinnamon- stick
Mace- small piece 1 Black cardamom
STEPS Crush the kiwi slice and apply on the lamb pieces. Keep aside for at least 30 minutes. Dry roast the dried chillies, coriander seeds and cumin seeds till a shade darker. Cool and grind to a fine powder. Heat oil in a pan. Add the ginger and garlic. Saute till raw smells goes. Tip in the lamb pieces and fry till a shade darker. Add the chopped onions and salt. Saute for a couple of minutes. Add the whole spices and give a stir. Add the powdered chilli mixture and water. Cover and cook till the lamb is cooked though. If you feel that the gravy is thin, you may cook on high heat till you achieve the desired consistency. Garnish with coriander leaves. Serve hot. All images and text on this website are protected by copyright. Please do not post or republish this recipe or images without permission. If you want to share this recipe just share the link rather than the whole recipe.
added.

INGREDIENTS
Grind to a Paste
Onions medium sized2
Medium sized Tomatoes1
Grated Coconut3/4 cup
Garlic6 Cloves
Kashmiri Red Chilies8
Coriander Seeds1 teaspoon
Whole Peppercorns1 teaspoon
Marble sized Tamarind Ball1
For the Curry
Surmai or Kingfish or Seer Fish600 grams
Turmeric Powder1 teaspoon
Coconut Oil1 tablespoon
Mustard Seeds1 teaspoon
Curry LeavesHandful
Coriander toppingA few Sprigs for
STEPS
Clean and wash the fish slices and rub turmeric all over them. Cover and keep aside. Grind all the ingredients under paste till smooth with a tablespoon or two of water. Heat coconut oil in a large pan or kadhai and add mustard seeds. Once the seeds start spluttering, add the ground paste and cook while stirring once in awhile for 10 minutes. Slide the fish into the pan, and add salt and 3/4 cup water. Mix gently so as not to break the fish. Bring the curry to a boil, and lower the heat to a simmer. Add curry leaves and simmer for 15 minutes. Top with coriander leaves and serve this spicy kingfish curry with steamed rice. .

WRITING.TEXT: That's one version. [Here's](http://stayhealthyandwell.com/fresh-vs-frozen-vs-canned-vegetables/) another. And some reports claim that these nutrients are known to escape during the thawing process for frozen veggies. Vitamin C and the B vitamins suffer the biggest nutritional losses in frozen fruits and vegetables, according to a 2007 study in the Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture. Levels of polyphenoic substances, which act as antioxidants to protect your cells from damage, also are lower in frozen food than fresh. Other nutrients, such as fiber, minerals, proteins and fat-soluble vitamins such as vitamins A, E and carotenoids retain their value in either frozen or canned fruits and vegetables.I'm not saying frozen vegetables are evil. But if you have the option of fresh, personally I would not go for frozen. Each to their own.

WRITING.TITLE: How To Make The Most Perfect Indian Makhani Gravy (Curry)

WRITING.TEXT: Find the full recipe [here.](http://www.myfoodstory.in/vegan-spinach-ginger-smoothie-bowl-recipe)

WRITING.TITLE: VEGAN SPINACH GINGER SMOOTHIE BOWL (1024/1024)
How To Make the Most Perfect Indian Makhni Gravy
WRITING.TEXT:
I saw this on a blog, tried it and it's just perfect.
**INGREDIENTS**
Butter4 tablespoons
Oil2 tablespoons
Green Chili1
Kashmiri Red Chilies4
Ginger Paste2 tablespoons
Garlic Paste1 tablespoon
Bayleaves2
Cinnamon Sticks2
Cloves5-6
Cardamoms2
Peppercorns1 teaspoon
Chopped Cashewnuts2 tablespoons
Khus Khus or Poppy Seeds1 tablespoon
Tomatoes, coarsely chopped14 large (1 1/2 Kg)
Garam Masala Powder1 tablespoon
Chili Powder1 teaspoon
Turmeric Powder1/2 teaspoon
Ketchup3 tablespoons
Sugar or Jaggery (Optional)1 tablespoon
Dry Kasuri Methi2 tablespoons
Fresh Cream2 tablespoons
Salt to taste
**STEPS**
In a large pan or kadhai, heat a tablespoon of butter and two tablespoons oil.
Add green chili, red chillies, ginger, garlic paste and whole spices. Saute for a minute or two and add cashew nuts, poppy seeds and tomatoes. Mix well.
Cover and cook this for ten to fifteen minutes till the tomatoes start breaking down.
Switch off the flame and set aside to cool.
Once cool enough to handle, fish out as many whole spices as possible, and grind the mixture to a smooth paste.
In the same pan or kadhai, heat the remaining butter and add the tomato paste.
Add garam masala powder, chili powder, turmeric, ketchup, salt and sugar or jaggery (if using) along with 1/2 cup water. Bring this to a boil.
Once the curry comes to a boil, simmer and cook for 30 minutes, till the oil separates slightly. In another pan, dry roast the kasuri methi and grind it to a fine powder.
Mix kasuri methi and fresh cream in the curry and switch off the flame. Let the curry cool completely before dividing it into smaller portions and freezing it in ziplock packs.
For full post click [here.](http://www.myfoodstory.in/how-to-make-indian-makhani-gravy-curry-recipe)

WRITING.TITLE: How To Make The Most Perfect Indian Makhani Gravy (Curry)

WRITING.TEXT: Glad this helps!

WRITING.TITLE: Goan Prwan Curry
WRITING.TEXT:
INGREDIENTS
750 gms Shelled and cleaned Prawns
2 tbsps Oil
7-8 Curry Leaves
1 large Onion Chopped
1/2 tsp Turmeric
2 Green chile
2 Kokum pieces ( Optional)
pinch of Sugar
to taste Salt
1 cup Fresh grated coconut
2 tbsps Coriander seeds
1/2 tbsp Cumin seeds
4-5 Dry red red chillies
4-5 Kashmiri red chillies
5-6 pods Garlic
1/2 tbsp Tamarind Pulp
STEPS
Clean prawns. Add little salt and turmeric. Mix well and keep aside. In a pan dry roast coriander seeds and Cumins seed till aromatic.
In a blender add grated coconut, roasted Coriander, cumin, red chillies, garlic. Add enough water and make a very smooth paste.
Heat a heavy bottom pan. Add 1 tbsp oil. Add prawns and Saute on high heat for not more than 3 minutes, stirring continuously.
Remove and keep aside. In the same pan add remaining oil. Add curry leaves. Add chopped onions. Saute till the onions are translucent and soft.
Add ground coconut paste and saute till the raw smell is gone. Add required amount of water to the pan.
Season it with salt (Keep in mind that the prawn marination also had salt in it) and sugar .Bring the gravy to a boil.
Once the gravy comes to a rolling boil add Kokum(If using) and sliced green chillies. Add sauteed prawns.
Let it cook for about a minute or so. Switch of the gas.
Note: 1.If you are using tamarind and Kokum both then adjust the quantities accordingly, as both contributes to the sourness. 2. The cooking time of prawn depends on its size,so judge it accordingly. Cooking prawns for too long results in rubbery prawns.
Find full recipe [here.](http://www.theflavoursofkitchen.com/goan-prawn-curry-recipe)

WRITING.TITLE: Goan Prawn Curry
Murgh Saagwala - Spinach Chicken Curry

WRITING.TITLE: Eggless Nutella Cake
WRITING.TEXT:
I wanted a recipe for eggless nutella cake without cocoa powder or cooking chocolate. So here goes. These are Ingredients to serve 5
1 1/2 cups All Purpose Flour 1 1/2 teaspoons Baking Powder 1 teaspoon Vanilla Powder 4 tablespoons Nutella 3/4 cup Sugar 1 cup Water 100 gm Butter 1 teaspoon Lemon Juice For Frosting
2 teaspoons Caster sugar 3 tablespoons Nutella Steps Sift together the flour and baking powder and keep aside. In a vessel, mix the water (Cold) and sugar till it dissolves. Preheat the oven to 200C. To the dissolved sugar add the 100 gm melted butter. Mix thoroughly. Now add the juice of the lemon and mix together. Then add the Vanilla powder and mix again. To this mixture add the sifted flour and baking powder mix. Whisk till no lumps remain. Add the Nutella to this and mix thoroughly. The final mix should not be thick. It should be a fairly thin consistency. Grease a 6 inch baking tray and pour this into that. Bake for 30 mins. Remove, allow to cool. Frost with some Nutella and top with castor sugar.
For the blog post and images. click [here](http://www.warandcheese.com/45-minute-eggless-nutella-cake-recipe).

WRITING.TITLE: Eggless Nutella Cake Without Cocoa Powder

WRITING.TITLE: How this food blogger made a small change to her ad strategy and made enough money to quit two full time jobs.

It talks about how Beth Moncel of the food blog Budget Bytes used optimised ads to get a lot more money than what she was making through ad sense. She talks about how exploring different ad networks and optimising ads worked best for her and why she doesn't believe ads are dead.

Medium is a great place to start blogging as it will help you focus on writing and creating great content. But your blog will not have an individual look and feel and if you are thinking of later building it into a monetizable blog, then Wordpress is a better option. But writing is super easy on Medium and everything look great with the least amount of effort.

Recipe *Ingredients to serve 1* 1 packet Paneer 3 tablespoons Nando's Peri Peri Sauce as required Oil *Steps* Cut the slab of paneer into two equal halves horizontally. Marinate with 1 1/2 tablespoons of Peri Peri sauce for 15 minutes. Heat a cast iron grill on the stove. Sprinkle very little olive oil. Add the Paneer steaks. Grill on both sides till nice and brown. Remove from grill. Add the remaining sauce on top. Serve with rice, peas and carrots.

WRITING.TITLE: Grilled Peri Peri Paneer Steak

WRITING.TEXT: No, not doing the larger than life Indian weddings. We are planning one with about 70 friends. Thankfully where i live is close to a beach, so planning a beach ceremony.
Yes, defo going for it :)
Thanks for this sweety. It really helps to know such stories. Yes we do know whats going to happen when kids come. Those sort of things we had discussed well before we even talked to our parents.
So we will do a court wedding and have an Hindu and Christian ceremony on the same day. It's going to be on the beach, so the pandit and priest are cool with this.

Absolutely, I completely agree. But we have had our clarity about this right from the beginning. Not saying we will not have issues later, but we are clear about the problems we will encounter. But we definitely want to do this. Coming to the ceremony: we are planning to do a bit of both, So we will do a court wedding and have an Hindu and Christian ceremony on the same day. It's going to be on the beach, so the pandit and priest are cool with this.

Basically we dn't really know what last minute things may comeup. Since there is no family support, we want to know as much of the things to deal with as we can. Basically we will just have a few close friends to help.

WRITING.TITLE: So our parents are not letting us get married. Sounds prehistoric, but true. We may need to do this on our own now, so all suggestions welcome!
WRITING.TEXT:
So, a little background here. I am India, so is my boyfriend. I'm Hindu and he is Christian. In India this is almost like being different species when it comes to marriage. He is my cousin's best mate. (that's how we met) After two years of dating (which is again super frowned upon on India) we decided to get married. And where we come from, it's still the parents that give the final nod to your partner (Weird, I know). So we tell both our folks. And initially they seemed to take it well and agreed to meet. After the meeting, his folks insisted that I convert, and my folks are insistent that I do not. (personally too I don't want to convert and neither does he) Now it's come to the point where his people are saying things like 'she is getting older'(i'm 27) and stuff and the parents are refusing to talk to each other. This lack of communication has been going on for about 7 months now. We are quite done with it. We have decided to do this on our own. So we need to know what things we will need to think of besides the obvious stuff. Guests, Legal stuff, Food, Clothes, Alcohol etc are the stuff we have started looking into so far.
Update: They have finally agreed!!!

One big advantage with Wordress is that it is more customisable. Not just with themes, but also the plugins and widgets and so on. Adsense is fairly easily integrated on Wordpress, easier still in my experience if you have a custom domain. But it totally depends on what you want to do with the blog. If it's a design heavy blog, I would suggest go with WP. Blogger has it's own advantages, it's fairly simple to use and easy to understand
any reason you chose blogspot?

There is definitely alot of money in blogging. Check this out to get some idea: http://pinchofyum.com/june-traffic-income-report
And as to resources, yes there are plenty of those. The kissmetrics website has a lot of insights, Neil patels blog is another good source. But it is not easy. It's hard work and the competition is super high. And it would also depend on what kind of blogging you are doing. Now banner ads are bringing in very little money, so you have to depend more on sponsored posts, affiliate marketing etc. So definitely hard to make a living, but not impossible.
